div.p: THE Damoiselles A LA MODE. A COMEDY.
Compos'd and Written by RICHARD FLECKNOE.

TO THEIR GRACES THE DUKE & DUCHESS OF Newcastle,
THE AUTHOR DEDICATES THIS HIS COMEDY MORE HUMBLY THEN BY WAY OF EPISTLE.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p: THis Comedy is taken out of several Excellent Pieces of Moliere. The main plot of the Damoiselles out of his Pretieusee's Ridiculee's; the Counterplot of Sganarelle, out of his Escole des Femmes, and out of the Escole des Marys, the two Naturals; all which like so many Pretieuse stones, I have brought out of France; and as a Lapidary set in one Jewel to adorn our English Stage: And I hope my setting them, and giving them an English foyle, has nothing diminisht of their native luster. And I have not only done like one who makes a posie out of divers flowers in which he has nothing of his own, (besides the collection, and ordering them) but like the Bee, have extracted the spirit of them into a certain Quintessence of mine own.

For the Language of the Pretieuse, it may be wondred that I durst attempt the Englishing it (so often attempted by our best English wits, and as often despaired of) it being a Language even new unto the French themselves, and so little understood by most of them, as they are forc'd to make a Dictionary for it apart; which notwithstanding I have done, and I hope with that success, as I have not only made the Language of the Author, English, but even the spirit, life, and quickness of it too.

For my Printing it before 'tis Acted, 'tis only to give the Auditors their Bill of Fare before hand; so far from taking away their Appetites of seeing it afterwards, as (on the contrary) if they like it, it increases it but the more; and if every one who writes for the Stage wou'd but do the like, there wou'd not be so much deceit in it as there is▪ Nor do I it to render it more publick, but only more legible, (few having patience to read more then a Letter in written
hand) and I may well say I have found out the secret of Printing, since written Copies communicated to many, and Printed only to few, are secrets alike.

For the Acting it, those who have the Governing of the Stage, have their Humours, and wou'd be intreated; and I have mine, and w'ont intreat them; and were all Drammatick VVriters of my mind, they shou'd wear their old Playes Thred-bare, e're they shou'd have any New, till they better understood their own Interest, and how to distinguish betwixt good and bad.

Mean time I suppose 'twill not be difficult for all who read this Comedy, to comprehend, how the VVorld's a a Theater, every place a Stage, all vvho read and understand, Actors
and Auditors, and there may be as good Playes now a daies not Acted, as Acted, at our Theaters, and by our Actors here.

div.head: THE INTRODUCTION.
div.stage: The Candles lighted, before the Curtain's drawn, Enter one of the Actors, another (suppos'd no Actor) calling after him.

sp.p: HArk you, hark you, whither away so fast?

lg.l: Why to the Theater, 'tis past three o'th Clock,
and the Play's ready to begin.
Stay a little, and I'le go along w'ye.
They say y'ave a new Play to day?

sp.p: We have so.
And who's the Author? who made it?
For that 'tis no matter, so the Play be good.

lg.l: By your favour, but 'tis though,
and a great matter too; for oftentimes
the reputation of the Author, is more
then half the goodness of the Play.
Let it suffice, 'tis one who has been more
then a Prentiship at the Trade,
and 'tis with Poets, and their Playes,
as with Potters, and their Vessels,
where (most commonly) your young beginners
Marr half a dozen
before they can make one.
But has he any Faction for him?
has he any to cry him up, in court or town?
else he'l be sure to be cryed down
before the Curtain's drawn, or Musick
play.
For that he's of an odd humour,
and says h'ad rather stand on his own legs,
then stalk on stilts of others favours.
That's the surest way indeed,
but t'other (now adays) the more plausible
And what thinks he of it himself? for
none can do any thing but by chance,
who knows not how well he does it.
For him to praise or dispraise it
were vanity,
and but to usurp
upon the priviledge of the Auditors,
only this he dares say, 'tis a Merry Comedy,
and he hopes will please all, but only such
as wou'd have Playes as serious as their business,
and as sad as Funeral Orations.
But let him not be too confident of it though,
for 'tis a Critical Age that finds out spots
even in the Sun it self;
and mens expectations
never deceive them more
then in others judgments of their Playes;
For him, he is so little presumptuous,
as he submits his Play wholly unto
the judgment of the Auditors
with this Protestation,
that he shall be as little offended with
those who shall justly find any fault with
it, as he shou'd be with those who
shou'd find any durt
or spot of durt,
on his Hat, or Cloaths, to brush off,
or wipe away;—
nay he shou'd take it
as a courtesie from them rather.
As for that
he shall find enough
to do him that courtesie
(I'le vvarrant him)
and me amongst the rest.

sp.p: Come, let's go then.

div.head: Of the Persons Represented, and Actors Representing them.
div.p: TOgether with the Persons Represented in this Comedy, I have set down the Comedians, whom I intended shou'd Represent them, that the Reader might have half the pleasure of seeing it Acted, and a lively imagination might have the pleasure of it all intire. The Scaenes & Cloaths being the least Considerable in it, any Italian Scaenes with four Doors serving for the one, and for the other any French Cloaths A la Mode.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
Intended for the Overture of the Theater, 1666.

lg.l: IN these sad Times our Author has been long
Studying to give you some diversion;
And he has ta'n the way to do't, which he
Thought most diverting, mirth, and Comedy:
And now he knows there are inough i'th Town
At name of Mirth and Comedy will, frown,
And sighing say, the times are bad what then?
Will their being sad & heavy better them!
Or rather won't their sad and heavy cheer
Make these our times worse then they ar appear?
Sadness for Physick may be sometimes good;
But cheerfulness shou'd be our daily food;
Without whose most delightful seasoning,
Even life it self were an insipid thing.
'Tis a great happiness when men are sad,
Divertisments may any wayes be had:
And we do hope our Comedy to day,
May so divert you, as you all shall say,
Whilst every one some Recreation has,
The best and most delightful ones, are Playes.

sp.speaker: Bonhomme.
sp.p: NAy but will you hear me a little?

lg.l: Perhaps I will, perhaps I will not.—
You don't come to chide me I hope?

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: No, but to give you good counsel rather.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: And that's little better then chiding.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: And to tell you as a friend what the world says of you.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: What care I what it says?

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: I there 'tis now! you care not for the world, nor the world for you; who live in't so sequestred from all society: You seem no more a part of the Universe, then a loose stone in a wall, a part of the building, or Edifice.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Well 'tis my humour, what then?

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Then y'ar as froward as young Children, as wayward as old age; and for courtesie and civility the chiefest bond of humane Society, y'ar a meer stranger to't, and know no more then the very Savages in America.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: What d'ye laugh! and are you not mov'd with this?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Yes to a little vanity or so, to hear so much of my Commendations.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: If you count this your commendations, what d'ye count discommendations I pray?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Why to be counted such a silly fool, to have them say of me, Oh! he's a very good! a very honest man!

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: And is goodness, and honesty, a discommendation with you then?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: I marry is it, as the world goes now adays, when it only serves to fool us, and makes us but a prey to every knave.—
And what do they say beside?

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Why since you'l needs have it, for Madmoiselle Isabella.—

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: I, what do they say of her?

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Why they say, she was not left unto your care by her deceased father, to be made a slave and prisoner by you.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: And was she left unto your care I pray?

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Why no, who says she was?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Then meddle with that you have to do withal,— you'd have me bring her up, I'le warrant you, as you do your fine Daughters there, to be always gadding abroad a visiting.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Or visited at home?

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: And that too?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: And have all your fine youths and Gallants of the Time (who stoop like Pyes or Dawes when they peck at fruit, alternaetly, their tayls above their becks) complement them, and give them Balls and Collations?

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: And what then?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Why then y'ar a fool, Cousin, and if you were twenty Cousins I'de tell you so;— for her, being committed to my care, either to marry her, or see her well marryed, I'le bring her up in manner as befits a wife, in the blessed state of ignorance, she shall see and know nothing; for this seeing and knowing too much, undid the first woman in Paradise, and has undone all your Women ever since.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Shu'd your Women but hear you, they'd claw out your eyes for this.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Then she shall have no Books to read in, for that but corrupts them at second hand; and if she had not learnt to write and read before her fathers death, she shu'd have never learnt for Sganarelle.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: And this you count good breeding now?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Better then your fine Daughters have, I wuss, to be always a' the mode, drest up unto the heigth, as if such Beauties simply of themselves, wear not darts killing and dangerous enough, but they must be poysoned too? no, I'le keep her untainted from the vanities of the Time.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Alas! you know she is too wise to be corrupted by them.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: No matter for that, I'le trust rather to mine own wisdom, then unto hers, and keep so strict a hand o're her, as she sha'nt be corrupted, though she wo'd.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: And I so gentle an one o're mine, as I hope they wou'd not, though they cou'd.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Well then since y'ar so resolv'd, take you your course, and I'le take mine, and see who'l have the better of it at the end.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Content, and see:
Here comes my Daughters— they have done their visit it seems.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: And Isabella with them! I like not that.

div.head: SCENA II.
div.stage: Enter Madmoiselle Anne, Mary, Isabella, and Lysette.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: ANd do's he coop you up so?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: So as you see.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nor suffers you to be visited by none.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: By none but you, and that he grumbles at too!

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: How d'ye pass your time then— learn to Preserve perhaps?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: I— to preserve her shooes, if she never stirs abroad.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And yet do's he make Love t'ye?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I, as Cats do, or High-Dutch to their Mistresses, you'd think they chid the while.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: And I'd scold as fast, were it to me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Come you shall go abroad with us and take the air.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: He'l never suffer it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'le warrant you.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Now! whither away so fast w'ye?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I tremble every joynt of me!

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Fie for shame!— e're I'd stand in such awe of any man, I'd see him hang'd, if he were worth hanging.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: W'ave intreated our Cousin here along with us to take the air.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: for you, you may go if you please; but for her, she shall tarry at home, I'le have no gadding with her.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Pray let me intreat for her this once,— we must allow youth some Recreation.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Youth's a fool, and Age is little better;— she'as Recreation enough at home, she needs not go abroad for't.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: What? to make you Night-caps! or piece your old Stockins at heels perhaps!

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: I'le none of these Recreations, I, in her whom I intend to make my wife.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Your wife! what shou'd you do with a wife I pray? a dainty Itch well scratcht, or Curry-comb neatly handled, wou'd do your business.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Peace, huswife, y'ar too bold.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Shan't we intreat so much for her this once then?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: No indeed Sha'nt you, and I'd intreat you to come and visit her no more if this be your business,— I fear she learns no good of you, so she does not.

lg.l: More then of you for all your
sowre countnance
and venegar meen— i'faith, i'faith were I
as she, if you shou'd use me thus, I'd make
you a Cuckold if ever I marryed you.
And were she
as you, I think she wou'd indeed;
but as she is, I'le look to her well enough,
she shall have none of your mothers
Daughters for Counsellors.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: And if she had, she'd be better counselled then by your father's son, I wuss.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Come, come, leave your prattle, and Daughters go you home, where y'ar to expect two honest Gentlemen, in nature of Suiters to come and visit you.

lg.l: Fine Gentlemen spoken scornfully.
I'le vvarrant them!

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: And look you use them kindly when they come, and entertain them well, d'ye hear?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Ne're fear it, we'l entertain them as they deserve.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Do so then— so go and take your leaves.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: I good Lady Eve begone and take your Tempter there, your waiting-woman along w'ye.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: I'faith, i'faith, were I your Tempter, I'd only tempt you to hang yourself, or so.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Go, go, begone I say, and I'le but only go dispatch a little business I have i'th' Town, and strait ways follow you.
As for you Cousin, I'ave only this to say t'ye before I go,—
Those who seek to be rather fear'd then lov'd, shall find themselves rather hated then fear'd at last,— and so farevvell.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Very good— and I've only this to say to you too before you go— let them hate me so they fear me, and so farewell to you again.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: So— now get you in and expect no more this liberty, d'ye hear? she whom I intend to make my wife, must imagine my house is all the world, and that there's no other company in the world but only she and I.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: bless me! that imagination wou'd make me desperate!

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: So— make your curtsie, and be gone,—▪ very good— and look to your business, d'ye hear!

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Which is only to be rid of you, which till I am,
I will be nothing but Plot and Stratagem.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Now let me think a little.

div.head: SCENA III.

sp.speaker: Valerio.
sp.p: YOnder's the waking Dragon that has my Golden fruit in Custody, I'd fain be acquainted vvith him.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Let me see, what am I about now? to marry— very good, an honourable calling! and if there be any pleasure and contentment in this life, your marryed man has it— I'le go marry presently, I am resolv'd on it.

div.stage: Valerio salutes him, and he minds him not.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: He sees you not, to him agen.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: But stay Sganarelle, consider a little first, how besides the care and trouble of wife and children, all marryed men, or are, or may be Cuckolds— hum! I'le none of't, marry who's list for me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: He's blind a' this side (sure,) I'le try the other.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Well, I'le take some further time to consider on't; mean time I'le out of Town assoon as I can, for there's no keeping a woman here without a hundred eyes.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: Now, now.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p:
Whoo! what a do's here, this is no English Quaker sure, he makes so many Reverences— agen? sure he's some
young Reveller, practising to make his honours here— with me Sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I have the happiness to be your Neighbour here hard by.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: It may be so.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I shu'd be glad of your better acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: And why so I pray?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Only to come and discourse w'ye sometime, o'th affairs o'th time, and news o'th Town, as who's marryed, to whom.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Let them be hang'd, what care I.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And what's said or done at Court, amongst the rest, d'ye hear the News Sir?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: No, nor I don't care to hear it.

lg.l: No fastning any discourse on him?
I perceive Sir you live solitary Aside.
and retir'd at home.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: What's that to you?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And shu'd be glad of company sometimes.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Who told you so?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And i'faith how d'ye pass your time at home.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Why, as I please my self.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You do very well in't, and so shu'd every one do that is wise; and if you please, I shu'd be glad sometimes to come and pass an Eve'ning w'ye, or so.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Serviteur.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!
If he fight at this ward as he speaks, I'le warrant any one for hitting him,— Now— what d'ye think of him, and of his brisk replyes?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why I think he's one of the race of the antient Spartans, or Pythagoreans, h'as so few words with him.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: And those he has, are all rusty, and want oyling; the whorson speaks nothing but old Iron and Hobnails.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Rather Daggers and Punyards that stab me to the heart;— what a misery is't to have her I love, guarded by such a Cerberus as he?

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: Rather 'tis your happiness; for take this from me, a Woman guarded, is half won; and he who but delivers her from her Guardian, gains the other half of her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I, but how to do't, there's all the difficulty.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: Think, think, have you no invention in you? I never saw a man so dull;— did you ever speak unto her?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: Nor writ unto her?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Neither.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: Why then y'ave done nothing yet;— has she no servants to make your confidents?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: None as I know of; only as often as she goes abroad, I follow her; nor do's the Hyacinth that amorous flovver, e're follovv the Sun vvith more assidual regards, then I do her.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: But do's she take notice of it?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That I knovv not neither.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: Why then you knovv nothing— think, think on some vvay to let her knovv your love for shame.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I but vvhat? the more I think on it, the more impossible I find it.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p:
Hang impossibilities! there's no such things in nature, 'tis hope enough, you love a Woman, and she a living one;
Pigmalion only lov'd the dead Statua of one, and yet (you see) he put life into it at last.— Think, think agen then, and I'le vvarrant you, the brain's a fertile soil; and let our vvit but sovv the seed, Time soon will ripen it.

sp.speaker: Sganarelle.
sp.p: SAy no more, I knovv the man, and the house he lives at— Valerio d'ye call him?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: So they tell me Sir.
Heaven prosper my plot, as my intent is innocent.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Go, go in, and let me alone vvith him: Gramercy for this Intelligence i'faith novv I see thou lov'st me.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I, as I do a Snake or Toad.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p:
I! are you such an one indeed!
I'm glad I knovv it,— no vvonder he made me so many Reverences, and desir'd to come and visit me,— I'le none of that I thank you; that vvere to let a Thief into my house, or Wolf into my sheepfold; but he that's vvarn'd is Arm'd, I'le to him strait, and tell him soundly of it;— but stay before I go, let me make all sure at home: Where are my Urchins? vvhere are my Changlings there?
HEre Master.
Here Master.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p:
These are all the servants I keep, or rather the Parish keeps them, and they serve vvell enough to keep my house, there's thrift and policy together novv: I suppose they vvill be faithful, 'cause they have not vvit enough to be othervvise, Come hither, you must stand modestly vvhilst I speak unto ye; hovv often have espyes them Playing.
I told you of this!
I must go abroad, d'ye hear?
I Master.
I Master.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: And be sure in my absence you look well unto my house.
I Master.
I Master.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: If any Trades-woman come, under pretence of selling their Ware, be sure you keep them out, for th'ar all Bawds, d'ye hear?
I Master.
I Master.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: As for the men, I need not tell you how dangerous it is to let them in who talk to women of nothing but fire & flames.
I Master.
I Master.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Then though your Mistress fall into a swound, be sure you let no Physician in unto her, for their looking to their waters is altogether as dangerous as t▪ others fires.
I Master.
I Master.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: So, being so well instrusted, ' go, look carefully to your charge, and my benediction w'ye.
I'le go for fear the Cat eat up my Bird.
And I for fear the Dog lap up my Porridge.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Now for my other business, this is the house as I take it.
Holla, who's within there?

sp.speaker: Valerio.
sp.p: VVHo knocks there? Oh Sir is it you, y'ar very welcome.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: I'le none of your welcomes.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: He's at's old ward agen.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Is your name Valerio?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: It is Sir, at your service.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p:
I'le none of your services neither, but I come to ask you whether you know that I am Guardian to a certain Damoiselle
call'd Isabella there.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I do Sir very well.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Well then, if you know it, I need not tell you so— next, if you know that, having the disposing of her in Marriage, I intend to marry her my self.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That I know not yet.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Well then, if you don't, I'd have you know so much, and that I take it very unkindly at your hands, that she can never stir abroad, but you are hanting her like a Ghost, and following her so, she may aswell be rid of her shadow, as of you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I Sir!

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: I you Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Who tells you so I pray?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Marry those who best can tell, even she her self.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: There's some comfort, she takes notice of thee yet.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: ‛ And besides she bids me tell you that she marks the amorous glances that you give her too.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: Ah, ha, Boyes! this works.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p:
And having perceiv'd thus much she wou'd advise you to take some other
course, for this won't do she says.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: Why this is clear, she's thine own I'le warrant thee boy.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: And this she says she wou'd have told you soon, but that she wanted opportunity of a fit messenger, and was loath to trouble me.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: A notable witty wench!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Well, Sir I'm sorry I've put you to this trouble, and pray tell her I follow her 'tis true, and look on her, with the same Reverence as adoring Persians look upon the Sun.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Pray lets have no more of your Reverence; w'ave had enough of them to day already, and for your looks pray keep them to your self, for if I catch you looking on her any more.—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Why then— I'd intreat you to look on some body else.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Oh! is that all?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: And so farewell unto ye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I dare not bid him farewell agen now, least he shou'd be angry— well what dost think of this?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: I've made him stare like a Pig! little did he look for such a message from her.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: Why she's done thy business to thy hand, and prevented thee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Peace he observes us, let us in, and think what use to make of it.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: I think I have put him to his dumps. I marry here's a vertuous woman now! that's offended if a man but look on her! where shall you find such another? and how long wou'd it bee're my Cousin's Daughters wou'd do so much, who dress up themselves a purpose to be lookt upon? but Isabella defyes them all, and I defie all the world to shew me such another; thanks to my care of her, and her good Breeding and Education.

div.head: Scaena VII.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Du Buisson, and La Fleur.

sp.speaker: La Fleur.
sp.p: VVEll, and what think you of our Entertainment now?

sp.speaker: Du Buis.
sp.p: Why I think, had we been of the lowest rank of men, no higher then Grooms and Foot-boys, they cou'd not have entertain'd us more scurvily, nor with more contempt and scorn.—
Proud pets! not so much as salute us, nor offer us to sit!

sp.speaker: La Fl.
sp.p: No, nor speak to us, and when we spoke to them, not so much as daign to answer us with yea nor no!

sp.speaker: Du Buis.
sp.p: Then there was such winking and whispering, such laughing and teehying with them?

sp.speaker: La Fl.
sp.p:
I, and such yavvning and rubbing of their eyes, vvith ever and anon
looking on their Watches, as if they thought the time too long, and vvere a vveary of our Companies.

sp.speaker: Du Buis.
sp.p: And at last they fairly rose and went away without so much as bidding us farewell:— But I know the reason of this, and if I do not fit them for't.—

sp.speaker: La Fl.
sp.p: As how I prithee?

sp.speaker: Du. Buis.
sp.p: Why I have observed your Damoiselles in Paris here, and almost all France over, are grown of late as mad with reading your modern Romances, as Don Quixot was with reading your ancient Books of Chivalry; and look that all who visits them shou'd be as mad and Romansick as themselves; and cause we were not so, they slighted us as they did; now will I cloath my Laquey like one of your Gallants, whom they admire so much, all Fool and Feather, and send him thither, and see how they'l entertain him.

sp.speaker: La Fl.
sp.p:
Content, and I've another as foolish and fantastical as he, who can imitate all their Cringes and Complements, talk bilk as loud and confidently as any of them, and throw himself
like a Tumbler after the Ladies, and he shall along with him.

sp.speaker: Du Buis.
sp.p: The more the merryer.— But see here comes their Father Monsieur Bonhomme, good honest Gentleman, one who speaks as he thinks, and does as he says, and means well and honestly in every thing.

sp.speaker: Bonhomme.
sp.p: THis Paris is nothing but noise and hurry, and one loses more spirits in a day with't here, then they can recover in a month in the Country.—
What Monsieur Du Buisson and Monsieur La Flour? my sons I hope they shall be! and how i'st ha? have you been with my Daughters?

sp.speaker: Du Buis.
sp.p: Yes we have seen them Sir.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: And how d'ye like them ha?

sp.speaker: La Fl.
sp.p: Their person's well, but their Entertainment not so well.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Du Buis.
sp.p: Nay for that y'ad best ask them themselves, and so we take our leaves and humbly thank you for all your courtesies and civilities.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Hovv's this? this is very strange and abrupt? I'le lay my life these scornful Baggages have said or done somevvhat novv that has offended them.— I shall knovv that presently, and if they have, they shall hear of 't soundly.—
Who's vvithin there?

sp.speaker: Lysette.
sp.p: VVHat's your pleasure Sir?

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Where are your Mistresses?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Above in their Closet forsooth.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: What a doing I pray.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Making Pomatum forsooth.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p:
Go call them hither presently.—
I'le no more of these Pomatums, they mean to undo me vvith them I think; I could keep half a dozen servants vvith the milk, vvhites of Eggs, and sheeps Trotters, vvhich they spend in daubing their fine Muzzles every day,— th'ar quite spoiled agen since their Mothers death, she kept them to their vvork, but novv there's nothing but idleness vvith them, and reading of these paltry Romances, that fill their heads vvith nothing but vvhimseys and vvindmills that are perpetually turning round;— vvou'd they vvere all burnt for me.

div.head: SCAENA IV.
div.stage: Enter Madmoiselle Ann, Mary and Lysette.

sp.speaker: Bonhomme.
sp.p: COme, vvhere are you?— and hovv did▪ you use those Gentlemen I pray, whom I recommended for Husbands t'ye that they are gone away so discontent?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Better then they deserv'd I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Fine Gentlemen indeed! to begin their addresses to us with Matrimony at first dash!

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: And how wou'd you have them begin, with Concubinage, I pray? I'm sure 'tas been the beginning of all who 'ave meant well and honestly ever since I was born.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Fie Father, how simply and vulgarly you talk? introth I'm, asham'd of you! had the Grand Cyrus begun with Mandana a' this manner, or else Aruns with Clelia, w'ad had a fine Romance no doubt of it, no longer then the Posie of a Wedding Ring.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: What have I to do with Aruns and Clelia, or the Grand Cyrus either?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Nay father my sister tells you right, for to begin with Marriage, was to begin at the wrong end, and to take the Romance by the tayle, as they use to say.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
No father, a hundred Adventures must precede, and a hundred Intrigues, before it comes to that; as first the Cavalier
must see the Lady in some Ball Temple or publick solemnity, and there fall desperately in love with her.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Then by some friend or near parent or so, he's to be brought to kiss her hands, when he's to endeavour by a thousand Gallantries, to gain her favour and good esteem.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But not a word of Marriage all this while, until at last in some Terrase or private walk i'th Garden, remote from Company, he's to declare his love unto her.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: When presently in mighty displeasure she's to leave him, and banish him her presence.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Then is he to pine, languish, and consume away, ('twould pitty you to see him) till at last by mediation of some friend, and's humble submission, her anger is appeas'd, his banishment revokt, and he restor'd unto her favour and grace agen.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: But not a word of Marriage, all this while.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Never have done!

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Till after a hundred persecutions of Parents displeasures, servants Treacheries, and Rivals Jealousies, with two or three duels at least (happy if he scapes with life) by mutual consent he's to steal her away at last, and so to marry her.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: I thought they'd never have done,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This father in true Gallantry now, is to marry a la mode, a la Belle maniere as they say.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Fidle fadle! without all these ceremonies and ado's, you shall marry these Gentlemen, and that presently, or I'le know why you shall not, do ye hear? you Mary and Anne, I say you shall▪

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh father! for heavens Love call us no more by those scurvy trivial names of Anne and Mary, able to spoile the best Romance as e're was writ.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Yet more Romances!

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
My Sister tells you true Father, and be you Judg your self, whether Amaranthe and Polixene, Names which w'ave chose ourselves, sound not a hundred times better then Mal and Nane, Names only for Orange women, able to shock any
curious ear; out upon't, I wonder you can endure to hear them!

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Go to, I say, I'le none of these Amarantha's and Polixens, but have you call'd by the names you were Christned by at the Font and Baptism, by your Godfathers and Godmothers.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Still Father will you be vulgar and trivial? to talk of Godfathers and Godmothers, Christendom, Fonts, Baptism, and I know not what, as if you were Catechising! when I pray did you ever read of these in a Romance.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: And when did I ever read a Romance I pray?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I that 'tis that makes you so ignorant as you are, if you had, i'faith you wou'd have better known what belongs to Gallantry and a la mode.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Mode me no modes, but leave these Fopperies, and marry these Gentlemen presently, or else you both go to a Nunnery, there's the short and the long of it: My shoulders are too weak I tell you plain, to carry any longer so heavy a burthen as tvvo such as you unmarryed in my house.

sp.speaker: An:
sp.p: For my part father I cou'd be vvell content to marry, so it vvere vvith one I likt.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: And what i'st you dislike in these I pray?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why a hundred things, first for a man to come a wooing in a plain and simple leg, without canons, a Hat without Feathers, and so horrible and furious an indigence of Ribbons and Garniture of his clothes, vvho cou'd endure it?

sp.speaker: An▪
sp.p: Then their Linnen vvas none of the finest, nor o'th best Linniners making neither:

sp.speaker: An:
sp.p: Besides 'tvvas all plain as my Sock vvithout, or point of Geneva, Venice, Ragusa, Sedan, or Oreliaek.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: What faults they find?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Besides their hair instead of falling handsomely and regularly unto curls, as it ought to do, either stood wildly staring up an end, or else hang loosly dangling down as 'f 'twere comb'd a' the German manner, only with four fingers and a thumb.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p:
Tush, toyes and trifles!
Tell me, are they not honest and proper men?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Proper enough I must confess to make Noble mens Porters, or Swizers of the Guard, and for their Honesties, they look indeed as if they had their Maiden-heads still, and that is as much out of fashion with Gallants, a't'other side▪

sp.speaker: An▪
sp.p: Then for their Language 'twas as unfashonable as their clothes, all clownish, savouring of the Country, far from the Elegance and Gallantry of Court, where they speak such douceurs, such dainty and delicate things, as 'tis a very Banquet for Ladies Ears:

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: Besides d'ye think we'd marry only with simple Gentlemen, without any honour or Titles to set them off, but bare Monsieur du Buisson and Monsieur LaFleur— one poor Hawthorn bush in France wou'd make four or five as good Gentlemen as they:

sp.speaker: Bonh▪
sp.p:
Come, all this is but trifling, and I'le hear no more of it: In a word, resolve to marry these Gentlemen, or you know what follows; for the rest whil'st y'ar in
the Town I give you free liberty to see and follow the fashion, visit, and be visited, do what you will, y'ar Mistresses of my house, and of your selves; but in point of Marriage I'le be Master, and so farewell.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Alas poor man, introth I pitty him! he is so simple and ignorant, I see the form was deeply sunk into the matter when he was born, which makes his brain so muddy ever since.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I must needs say he's a very honest man; but for the Mode and Gallantry 'tis terra incognita to him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This comes o'th want of reading Romances now; I'le warrant ye they re'd nothing when he was young, but only Homelies and dull Morality.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Or at best but the History or Barlaam and Iosaphat.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Introth I have wondred with my self a hundred times, how one so heavy and dull as he, cou'd ever beget so lively and sprightly a child as I! sure he's none of my Father, but I am Daughter of some
King, or Emperour, lost in my Cradle by some strange accident, and look e're long, by one as strange for to be found agen,— I've read of as strange things as these have come to pass.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: And I look to marry some Duke or Prince, or Marquis, or Count, at least; I was a dream'd of one last night.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: NOw! what news with you?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Yonder's one Marquis Mascarillio, forsooth, has sent his Valet to know if you'l be within this Afternoon, and please to be visited.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Oh sister! my dream as right as may be.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Go tell him he shall much honour us, but will you never learn to denounce handsomly, and a la Mode?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Why forsooth?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You shou'd say now, yonder's Marquis such an one, desires to be informed whether you please to render your self visible or no.
This now is to speak your precious Language, and a la mode.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Well, go and dispatch the Messenger with an answer affirmative, and when you come agen, we'l read you a lecture of it.—
Oh my Toutebonne, now w'ar in pass to be famous indeed, when no less then Marquisses come to visit us!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I, this 'tis to live in Paris now, we might have liv'd in the Country long enough, e're ever we had had this honour.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Well, have you dispatcht the Messenger?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
Then hearken to your Lesson,— Always before Company, be sure you elevate your stile, and speak a Language which none may understand but the Pretious Cabal,—- that which they understand not they'l admire, and admiration
begets Esteem and Reverence.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: As for example, go presently and fetch me my Zephirus hither.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Her Zephirus! what's that!

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: She means her Fan you fool.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Oh! is that her Zephirus.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And bring the Councellor of the Graces along with you.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: The Councellor of the Graces! what's that I wonder?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Her Looking-Glass she means.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Oh now I understand.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And look you do not soil and sully it with reflexion of your Phisiognomy.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: This now is to speak the pretious Language, and a la mode, which 'twere to endear on Ridiculousness it self, for any Damoiselle a la mode to be ignorant of.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This, only to give you a tast of it, for this time is enough; go now and make ready the House as we shall do our selves, against he comes, and look you perfume the Rooms till we may loose our selves in the precious miste.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: I go forsooth.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Marquis Mascarillio d'ye call him! oh my dear! what a fine name is that?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And he's as fine a man I'le warrant you.

div.head: SCAENA VI.

sp.p: COme, now let's Play a little 'till Master comes.
Content; Hi, hi, hi, hi, hi.

div.stage: They play a many fools Gambols.

sp.p: No, but I'le teach you a fine Play now,— See saw, see saw.
Nay now you play foul play, so you do.
Foul play! what's that?
Why 'tis— to play foul play.
Oh now I understand.
Now stand you there, and I'le stand here— and I'le lay you a wager I'le meet you before you shall meet me.
Come on then:
Lo ye there now.
Nay I met you first.
But you did not:
But I did.

lg.l: Who's within there?
Open the door here.
'Uds so! 'tis Master knocks;
Go you and let him in.

sp.p: Go you and you will.
I won't.
And I wont neither.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Will no body come there! are ye all deaf? I'le make you hear.

lg.l: 'Uds so, Master's angry.
I'le go and open the door.

sp.p: Nay, I'le go.

div.stage: They strive, and open it betwixt them.

sp.p: But you shan't.
But I will.

div.head: SCAENA VII.
div.stage: Enter Sganarelle, and whilst they fight, all the blows light on him betwixt them.

sp.p: I'le teach you to take my office from me.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Why how now! what's the matter? hold, hold I say, what beat your Master? Nay if you'l needs fight, I'le fight with you.
Oh, oh, oh.
Oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Here's fine doing indeed! 'tis time to look to you!
Go leave your bawling, and call your Mistress presently.
I'le go.
Nay I'le go.
But you shall not.
But I will.

div.stage: They strive to go out together, and are set in the Door▪

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p:
Agen! agree, or I'le make you agree. So this is fine! I'le set you going with a vengeance.— Shoves them in▪
Now I know she longs to hear what news I bring.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: I'Ve done an Act here, of so bold a strain as well might put a Virgin to her shame; but Love and my extream necessity, or never blush, or let them blush for me.— Well ha' ye been there?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: I have.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: And what says he?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Why he says, He looks upon you or so, sometimes 'tis true, but he means no harm by't.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: And wou'd you believe him? y'ad best say he meant no harm by this too. Just now as I was standing at my Window to take the air, who shu'd come by but he? and what did he? but just as I turn'd my back, threw me this Box with this Letter in it here, into my Chamber:

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: How a Letter!

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I, and when ha'd done, away he went like Lightning, or I had thrown it like a Thunderbolt at his head;— insolent as he is! to offer to send his Letters unto me!

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: What's in't dost know?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Not I, nor desire to know.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Why hast thou not re'd it then?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Not for a world; for but imagin Sir, what dishonour 'twere to me, and encouragement to him, if he shu'd think, I'd the vicious curiosity to open and read his Letters!

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Let me see't, I'le read it then.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: That were the same, for then he'd think 'twere I;— no pray Sir let me send it back as 'tis.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Well go thy ways for a mirrour of Prudence and Discretion!

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Besides words are but air, but when inclos'd in Letters once, I shou'd think their poysnous damp wou'd kill me presently, shou'd I but open them;— cou'd I but find one now to send it by.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: I'le do't, I'le do't.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: And tell him how I scorn to read his Letters.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Let me alone.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Yet Sir, to satisfie your Curiosity, you may read it if you please.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Not I, I promise you, without an Antidote, if 't, be so dangerous as you say it is.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Well, then pray carry it him as it is; methinks I am in pain until he have it.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: I'le soon rid thee of that pain I'le warrant thee, and assure thy self I'le marry thee a week sooner then I thought to have done, only for this my little pretty Rogue.

sp.speaker: Isab:
sp.p: His kindness and unkindness equally do's kill, As poyson, though sugred, is poyson still.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p:
I, are you good at writing Letters i'faith? I'm glad I know it; you shall find that I'm as good at carrying them.— Now cou'd I preach against Love Letters, and bid your Damoisells by her example take heed of them; for just as Mountebanks
wrap up their poysonous Drugs in paper, so if you look on the outside of these Letters th'ar are only paper, but open them and look on them within, you find them poyson, very poyson, the bane of Virginity, the ratsbane that makes them swell agen;— methinks I'm in an excellent vein of Preaching now.—
But to my business, holla, who's within there.

sp.speaker: Ergasto.
sp.p: vvho's there? what Monsieur Sganarelle? your pleasure Sir?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Pleasure me no pleasures, where's your friend? your friend Valerio there, that is so good at writing Letters.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: He's not within at present.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p:
No matter, there give him that Letter, and tell him, his piece won't off, his powder's damp, and wont take fire,
h'as mist of his aim this once.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: What's all this!

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: In plainer terms, tell him, Isabella scorns to read his Letters, but h'as sent it back to him, as 'twas sent to her.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: I understand nothing of all this now?

sp.speaker: Sgan:
sp.p: And d'ye hear? take notice I pray that I deliver it as 'twas delivered Seal'd and unopen'd, & so farewell.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: What shou'd the meaning of this be I wonder?

sp.speaker: Valerio.
sp.p: O Hi I'm glad y'ar come.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: Here has been your old Messenger agen.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Who! Sganarelle?

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: The same, and he has left this Letter for you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'Tis not a Challenge, is it?

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: if it be, 'tis from Isabella, for she sent it he tells me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: From her! Oh give it me straight then, that I may kiss it a thousand times; how's this? the Superscription is to her!

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: But open it, and see from whom the Subscription is.

lg.l: IF I have rightly interpreted your Love,
I hope you will not be so unjust
to misinterpret mine; I am here in the hands
of one I hate, and if you deliver me not
the sooner, death shall; mean time
I am the miserablest alive, unless you find
some way to make me happy.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: Now, what think you of this piece? i'st not an Original!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes Ergasto, and that of such a hand I shall think it no Idolatry to adore: Now I perceive she is as wise as fair, and I am happy, nor shall I ever rest till I have made her so:

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! what an Ass has she made of him? to make him carry this himself!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Peace, here he comes.

sp.speaker: Sganarelle:
sp.p: IT do's me good to think how blank he'l look when he receives this Letter; I long to see him, and laugh at him: Now Sir y'ave receiv'd your Letter?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I have so Sir.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: And you perceive by it the difference of persons, and how some have the happiness to be belov'd, and others not?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I do so Sir, and must have patience.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Poor man! he's ready to cry agen;— well, and what service will you command me back? you see, I'm good at carrying Messages.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why you may tell her Sir, that as I only live for her so I shall die to serve her.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: The poor man's even desperate I see?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And for this Letter here which you esteem so high disgrace, tell her I take it for the highest grace and favour she cou'd do me.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Even much good do't ye with't, and when w'ar marryed, you shall come if you please and give her thanks for it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How marryed!

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Yes, I'le invite you to my Wedding.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: Can you endure this?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Peace, inconsiderate man? i'st fit that I shu'd offend him, who has power to injure her?— I'le fright him yet, and see what that will do,— Hark you Sir, methought I heard you talk of marrying Isabella.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: I did so Sir, what then!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why then y'ad best to make your Will before, or see me dead, 'twill be dangerous else, and say, I told you so.

sp.speaker: Sgan:
sp.p: How's this! the mans desperate I think indeed; if he be such an one, I'le not invite him to my Wedding beshrew me: Hark ye Sir, now I better consider on it, I mean to be marryed privately▪

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Talk of Marriage agen?

sp.speaker: Sgan:
sp.p: Cry mercy Sir, if you be so angry I'm sorry I've troubled you, and so farewell:— I'le no more Messenges if he be such an one.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.p: So, this will defer his Marriage a vvhile I hope, till I may think on some prevention, but what I can't imagin?

sp.speaker: Erg:
sp.p: Come n'er torment nor vex your self, but leave it all to her; imprison'd winds either inforce their way, or cause an Earthquake; so now sh'as begun she'l ne're give o're, till she has throughly done:

div.head: Scaena I.
div.stage: Mascarillio brought in, in a Chair by two Sedan-Men.

sp.speaker: Mascarillio.
sp.p: HOlla, holla, these baptiz'd Mules I think have a plot to break my bones, they do so joult and jostle their Chair against every post they meet.
The Entry's strait Sir, and you'd be carryed in.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: And good reason, Goodman Faquin, d'ye think I'd expose my Feathers to the humidity of the air, and shoes to the rude assault of Paris dirt?
So now take up y'ur luggage and begone.
You'l pay us first, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: How!
Our Money Sir.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p:
Was ever heard of such an Insolence,
to demand money of me?
How wou'd have us live Sir, if you do not pay us?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: If you can't live without paying, there's payment for you, and there— saucy Rogue, to demand money of such Gallants as I!
But we'l be paid in another manner Sir, before you go, for all your Gallantry.

div.stage: Takes out the Lever of the Sedan.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: How now! what mean you?
Or pay us our Money, or—

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Hold, hold! there 'tis; now thou ask'st it in good manner, and as thou oughts, but that's an unmannerly Rogue there:— Now, are you satisfyed?
Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Then begone and leave me.
Stay Sir, now I'le be paid for your beating of me too, before we go, or else.—

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p:
Hold, and good reason, there's somewhat for thee too; you shall find me the reasonablest man i'th world, when you ask things in good manner, and as you
ought. Now are you satisfied?
Yes, I thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: No, thank your Ignobility you Rogues; for, but I scorn to draw my Sword upon such base Faquins as you, by this bright steel I'd kill'd you both e're this— this excuse I learnt of a Gallant who was beaten by a Hackny-Coachman t'other day.— Well, get you gone now, and take heed of provoking my fury another time.
At your service Sir.
We hope you can't say but w'ave us'd you civilly?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: I, I, I must needs say that:— So, thus far I have play'd the Gallant right, never to fight when I can help it; nor pay debts, but when I cannot choose:— Now for the Ladies, which is the main business of your Gallants in the world, and when there are no more to Court and Complement, they may go out of it, as having no more to do.

div.stage: He sings, Adjusts his Canons and Feather, Surveys himself, & does all the Antick tricks Of a Fantastick Mounsieur.

sp.speaker: Lysette.
sp.p: MY Ladies desire you to have a little patience, Sir, and they'l instantly wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: No hast, no hast, my pretty Carryer of Messages; I can entertain my self well enough here the whil'st, with contemplating the Historical Ornaments of the place.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Methinks this Monsieur in these clothes, and that feather there, looks just like some Amphibious Animal, half Bird, and half Baboon.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Now don't I know whether in true Gallantry, I were not to fall on the Waiting-woman first; I have a gallant Itch come upon me, and cannot hold: Hark you, hark you sweet heart, suppose one shou'd ask you an Enigmatical Question now?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Excuse me Sir, I'm none of those I can assure you.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Right!— Thus whatsoever they understand not, they interpret strait to.— you know what:— Come, come, there's somewhat for thee; you must not be so coy— you understand me.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Yes very well Sir.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Or else thou wert no right Waiting-woman:— Come then.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Soft Sir, another time▪ I hear my Ladies coming.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: This now is another trick of Gallantry, to have Wenches cozen them of their money.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: And see th'ar hear.

div.head: SCAENA III.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Hai day! this Mounsieur has got the French staggers right.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Most fair, and most accomplisht Ladies, If I importune you with my visit, 'tis your perfections have brought this trouble on your selves, of which I am so great an Idolater, as where e're 'tis found, I needs must go to reverence and honour it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Noble Sir, there's no perfection here, but only what you bring along with you.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Now by your fair Eyes Ladies, which like Suns, illuminate all this other Hemisphear; your Graces and Perfection are so great, as for Wit, Beauty, and true Gallantry, you pic, repic, and Capot, all the Ladies in Paris else.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: You may say what you please Sir, but we are not so vain to lend the serious of our belief, unto the Raollery of your Complement,— I marry sister, this is a brave man indeed! you may see Nobility in his very Meen!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I, and in's fashion and behaviour too! who's there? some Chamber Pulpits strait.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
Some Chairs, They set Chairs.
some Chairs there,— please you Sir to sit, here's a Chair that stretches forth its arms, and shou'd be glad and proud o'th honour of embracing you.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: All here speaks civility even to the Chairs and Stools; but pardon me Ladies, I wou'd fain tarry, but I see certain dangerous eyes here, that look as if they'd kill men, or rob them of their liberties at least.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: We'l warrant you Sir.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Well Ladies, on your security I'le venture this once; nor can I sacrifice my Liberty any where better then at the Altar of your feet.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Don't ye admire him Sister?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Admire him! I am rapt a thousand degrees beyond Admiration!

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: And what think you of my Feather Ladies?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Oh, 'tis the very top, and top-gallant of all I ever saw! and you'r the true Estridge, t'other but a counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: And my Canons.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh most heavenly wide!

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: I can assure you there's more in them by half an Ell Paris measure, then in any are worn in Town beside.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I never saw the Elegance of Adjustement carryed so high by any one before!

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I Sister, this 'tis to know the fine of things, the superfine, the very fine of fines!

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: And how long Ladies is it since you made this Town happy with your Residence and abode?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: So short a time Sir yet, as we count only by days the age of our being here.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: And what d'ye think of Paris? is it not the Paradice of all Delights! the Treasury of all that's rich and precious, and compendium and abridgement of all wonders and rarities!

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: 'Tis incontestible truth Sir; and I do not see, I protest, how 'tis possible for any Lady to be sav'd out of Paris here.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Why now you ravish me! and what Recreations have you had since your arrival here?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O Lord Sir! w'ave had so horrible a want and dearth of them, as w'ar even starv'd and famish'd agen.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: I'le carry you to the next new Play that's play'd, but then you are oblig'd to cry it down what e're it be, 'tis the fashion of your Gallants now, and will get you the reputation of Wits.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: That Sir we shall not fail to do, before the Musick plays, or Curtain's drawn.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: And what acquaintances, Ladies, have you made, since you came to Town?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: None at all Sir yet.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: I'le bring you acquainted with all the Wits of the new Collection, they come unto my Chamber every day; and but this morning I'd a dozen of them there; nay, if please, they shall keep an Academy at your Lodging every week.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: O Lord Sir, you'l infinitely oblige us, for only such as they, govern the Fames of the Ladies here in Town, and with a Copy of Verses cry them up, or Lampoon, cry them down, when e're they please.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Right; and besides, they can inform you to a half Stanza of all the Verses that are made in Paris every day, as who made a Madrigal of's Mistress Beauty, who an Ede of enjoyment, who sent an Elegy to his Mistress over night, and the answer she made unto't by next day noon.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I, these are things to be known 'bove all your dull Morality and Philosophy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I, and Divinity too Sister.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Still Ladies you ravish me more and more; and since I see y'ar delighted with Poetry, I'le recite you some compositions of mine own.

sp.speaker: A:
sp.p: Beseech you Sir.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: For you must know I've a Poetical itch sometimes, and scratch for it on paper too; amongst the rest you shall hear recited in all your most celebrous Assemblies here, some hundred Songs and Sonnets of mine, as many Odes and Elegies, a thousand Madrigals, and Epigrams sans number.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p:
And I'ave a very furious Tender
for those Epigrams, methinks th'ar the finest things!

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: And for those I shall fit you, for I am turning all Roman story into Epigrams.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And that must needs be rare and excellent! but touching the Verses Sir, you promis'd us.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: You shall have them as soon as I can intreat them of my Memory; and these they are, made of a Ladies stealing my heart away, imagin it your selves.

lg.head: The VERSES.
lg.l: Ah, ha! and have I caught you (as they say,
Mos did his Mare) stealing my heart away.
And wo'd you run awaywith't wheny ' avedon;
I'faith, i'faith, for all you'd fain be gone,
I'le make you dearly pay for't e're you part;
Stop Thief, stop Thief, my heart, my heart, my heart.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Rare!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Excellent!

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: The best as e're I heard!

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p:
D'ye mark that Ah, ha! at my entrance into stile, what a natural Expression it is, as much as to say, are you
there i'faith? or have I caught you? as I express it afterwards ah, ha!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That ah, ha, alone is worth a whole Epick Poem.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Then have I caught you as Mos did catch his Mare; there's an Erudition for you now? taken neither from Greek nor Latin, but from an English Proverb, nothing savouring of Homer nor Virgil, and a thousand degrees at least remov'd from the Scholar or Pedant.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I, and a thousand, and thousand more to that!

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: But you'd be ravish'd now to hear the air, I've set unto't.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: Why are ye a Musician too! have you learnt Musick Sir?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Not learnt it, but such Gallants as I, know every thing without learning.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Assuredly my dear?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pray let's hear it Sir.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: You shall, but you must consider 'tis a la Cavalier, hem, hem, ah, ha! &c.

div.stage: He sings hoarcely and ridiculously with all the Grimaces of an affected Singer.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Oh! most divine! the very Harmony of the Spheres.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'm enthusiasm'd with it!

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: 'Tis pure Chromatick, this!

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Methink 'tis pure Caterwouling, if this be a la Cavalier, I have enough of it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Did you mark the humouring of the words? how at stealing, the Musick stole away, as 'twere, and then at running, it ran away as fast.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: We did, and admir'd it.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Besides, if you markt it at the word stop Thief, there was such a Hubbub, as you'd have thought a whole Heu and Cry had been following, the rest was in stilo Recitativo.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: This 'tis now to know the heigth and depth, the longitude, latitude, and every dimension of Art!

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: I can hold no longer, ah, ah!

div.stage: Crys vehemently out, they start up.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What ayle you Sir?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p:
Now by your soft and sweeter bosoms Ladies, those perfum'd pillows that love does rest upon! you even ravish
my heart out of my breast; methinks it hangs only by a slender string: Oh, oh, oh! I languish, faint, and die!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Does he not do it rarely Sister? those two Monsieurs who came a wooing to us, are not worthy to be his Laquys.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I have a certain curiosity to know if he be marryed, or no.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I, are you there Sister? I'm glad I know it▪

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: And are you jealous Sister? I'm glad I know that too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now what's the news with you.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Yonder's one Count Iodelet without, desires to know whither you please to render your selves visible.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh! I see you'l learn in time.

sp.speaker: Mas:
sp.p: How Count Iodelet?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I, do you know him?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Know him! my only Comrade in all our former Warrs; why Piladis and Orestes, and Damon and Pithias were meer strangers and enemies, compar'd unto us two.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: Go introduce him strait.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p:
Count Iodelet! now Ladies I'le
promise you, you shall see the gallantest man in France, and bravest Soldier, brave upon brave, a three pyld brave.

div.head: SCAENA IV:
div.stage: Enter Iodelec fantastically habited a la Soldatesque, Lysette, &c.

sp.speaker: Iodelet.
sp.p: VVHat Marquis, art thou here?

sp.speaker: Mas▪
sp.p: Count! I am ravisht to see thee, go and salute these Ladies, that afterward I may more freely pour out my self into thy Embraces.

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p: By your fair leave Ladies.

sp.speaker: Mas:
sp.p: And how dost, ha! thou lookst somewhat pale methinks!

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p: The fatigues of the War, and Vigils of the Court, but I'm resolv'd to leave it, there's no reward for men of our merits and deservings now a days, who have lost our lives in our Countrys service.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: I, the Children of peace carry all away novv, from us the sons of War.— And hovv long i'st i'faith since thou and I met first i'th Warrs.

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p: Let me see— some sixteen years as I take it▪

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: 'Tis more, 'tis more man, by the same token thou commandst a Regiment of Horse on the Gallies of Malta.

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p: I, we had hot service there.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: But not so hot as afterwards at taking the half Moon at siege of Graulin.

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p: Half Moon! 'twas a whole one man, thou hast forgot.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: I think it was indeed, I'm sure I've good reason to remember it, for I receiv'd this Musquetad there,— pray Ladies vouchsafe to feel here.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: A very terrible wound indeed!

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: I feel nothing but only the nape of his neck.

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p: And I, this other coup de Granad, pray Ladies stoop, and feel here.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: A horrible one too!

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p:
There's nothing but only the hollow of his Ancle; I think these Gallants
swear nothing but Wounds, there's so many Wounds with them.

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p: But now I'le shew you a terrible one indeed.

div.stage: Offers to put down his Hose.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Oh no, we beseech you Sir, w'ave seen enough already, you'l fright us with sight of more.

sp.speaker: Iod▪
sp.p: Well, as you please; these are honourable marks and signs what men are.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: And that's the reason it seems your Gallants now a days, especially in Ladies companies, stand with their hands in their Codpieces only to shew what men they are.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: And when didst see the Duke thine old Comrade?

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p: We supt together yester night, and h'as invited me for to morrow to hunt the Stag with him; wilt ' be o'th party sirrah?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: I'faith, I cannot, I'm oblig'd to wait on the Duchess thou wot'st of, out of Town.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Th'are acquainted with all the Grandees of the Town it seems?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: More honour for us to be acquainted with them.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: But we neglect the Ladies,— Sirrah as thou camst in, these Ladies and I were discoursing of Verses, and thou art excellent at them I know.

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p: A little at Inpromptuses or extempore ones.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And that's the very Touchstone of a prompt and ready wit!

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Thou shalt make some of these Ladies here.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: We beseech you Sir.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: And the subject shall be of their fair eyes.

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p: You put me strangely to it, Marquess, but I'le try.

p.hi: Of your fair Eyes Ladies what shu'd I say? what shu'd I say?

div.stage: Repeats them, and is at a stand.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: I think he knows not what to say indeed.

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p: Pox on't, I can easily make the first verse; all the difficulty is, to make the second Rhyme unto't.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: I think so too.

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p:
Well Ladies, pardon me this once I have lately let blood so much in thee
Poetick vein, as my Muse is but weak and feeble yet, but assoon as I shall have recover'd a little strength, you shall see I'le make you as good extempore Verses (with a little study) as ever you heard.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Mean time what shall we do? shall we carry these Ladies abroad to take the air?

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p: Content, thou hast thy Coach here Marquess, hast thou not?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Not I, I came in a Chair.

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p: And I've sent mine away.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No matter, 't shall be for another time;— shall we have a Ball then?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: I, but for the Violins? the Animaters of the feet, and paradice of the Eares?

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p: I'le send one of my Valets for them; holla, who's there without? Basque, Lorrain, Piccard, Burquenot, Bretain, Gascoin, Norman, Perigot, none of these Valets there? par la mort bleu, there's never a Signeur in all France worse serv'd then I, I think.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Faith, and I think so too.

sp.speaker: Iod▪
sp.p:
To have never a Valet at hand
when one has most need of them!

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: The devil of Valet did they bring along with them.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: No matter, ours shall go; but then for filling parts unto our Ball 'twill be too empty else.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: We'l send to invite our Neighbours here hard by, amongst the rest Lysette you shall go to our Cozen Isabella's, and see if the clown her Guardian will let her come:

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: I know he will not, wherefore 'tis in vain.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: No matter, she shall go only to vex him;— mean time please you to honour us so much to accept of a slight Banquet w'ave prepar'd within, you shall infinitely oblige us.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Y'ave abundantly regall'd us Ladies with your fairer sights, but we shall wait upon you.

div.head: SCAENA V:
div.stage: Enter Sganarelle, Lysette, stealing in after him.

sp.speaker: Sganarelle.
sp.p: SO, I'm glad I'm come home; were I the King, I'd make a Law against this saluting and complementing, the very Rack of coversation that sets every ones joynts a stretching, with I'm your humble servant, and I know not what;— your Porters Salutation with a thump o'th back at meeting, and a kick o'th breech at parting, is not half so troublesome.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: I've stoln in after him, and he'l wonder to see me here.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p:
I like your Hollander yet, who goes plodding about his business, and never troubles himself nor others with good manners;— besides, 'tis the very University of lying, for they'l tell you th'are your servants, when they think themselves far better men then you, and say th'ar
glad to see you well, when they'd be far more glad to see you hang'd.

sp.speaker: Lys▪
sp.p: Now will I shew my self.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: How now? how came you here?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Why thorough the door, which way else shu'd I come? you don't take me for a Lapland witch I hope, to enter by the Chimney riding upon a broom-staff?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: I do not know;— and what wou'd you here I pray?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: I'd only speak with Madamoiselle Isabella▪

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: And from whom?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: From my Ladies.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: And what to do I pray?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: This man wou'd make an excellent Catechist:— why they'd intreat her company at a Ball.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: A Ball!

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Yes, there's the Marquess Mascarillio and Count Iodelet at our house, and they'd desire her to come and bear them company.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p:
Why th'art not mad? or dost thou think me so? that I shu'd suffer her go unto a Ball, especially in such company
as those; I'le send her to the Burdell rather.

sp.speaker: Lys:
sp.p: Why I hope you take my Ladies for honest women? and I can assure you th'ar very honest Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: No matter for that, your women may be honest women, and men honest men, but put them together once, and I'le not answer for their honesties.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: You won't let her go then?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: No indeed won't I, and get you gone the sooner, or I'le set you going.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: And can you find in your heart to deny me then?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: I indeed can I, and beat you too if you get you not gone the sooner.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: I who am so much your servant.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: She's at her Complements!

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: And have always spoke so well of you▪

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: I so you did to day, if you be remembred.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: And said, that Isabella wou'd be most happy in marrying you, and that I wondred at my heart that every one was not in love with you.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: And are you lying too?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Now tell me in conscience don't you think this true now?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Perhaps I do, what then?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Why then y'ar an Ass to believe any one can be in love with that Owles face of yours, and those Asses ears, which one wou'd swear wear horns, if you were but marryed once.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Why thou damn'd Baggage, how how darst thou provoke me thus?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Or that proper person of yours half Bear, half drill, and all a Beast.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: If I cou'd catch you▪

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: And so I humbly take my leave, and rest your most humble servant.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: She's at her Complements agen! this woman is a compound of all women together, and h'as more ingredients in her then Mithridate or Treacle, but the main is Mercury and Quick-silver.
But vvhere are my Urchins, vvhere are my changlings there? I'le talk vvith them for this.
HEre Master.
Here Master.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Come hither you egrigious Ideots.
Uds so Master's angry.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Did not I charge you to let no Trades-woman in, because I said they were all Bawds? and do you let waiting women in now? look better to your charge, or
sp.stage: They tumble over one another for fear.
sp.p: I'le so bang your fools coats, I'le make them stick like playsters to your sides:— Go call your Mistress, and leave your Tumbling tricks.
I must not let her know▪
she's invited to a Ball, for fear of stiring up light species in her mind.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: HE never sends for me, but I'm afraid my plot's discover'd; but custom of fearing now, has almost made me fearless: Well, have you deliver'd the Letter?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: I, I'ave paid him in his own coyn I think.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: And what said he?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: A great many good morrows, I know not what, but I've pour'd water to his vvine I'le warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Rather oyle to his fire, for he is grovvn more violent and outragious then ever.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Hovv so?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Why as I'm credibly inform'd, he intends a terrible Ryot on your house, and to come to night and take me avvay by force.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p:
Methought he talkt somevvhat
desperately indeed; but hovv come you to intelligence of this?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Why this Note vvith a stone vvrapt in't vvas throvvn into my Chamber vvindovv, I knovv not by vvhom.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: I must have that window damn'd up.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: But I imagin by one of my Cozens.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Very like; and what shall we do then?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Why go to him, and tell him soundly of it, ask him if he been't asham'd; you deal too gently with him, tell him I desie his worst, let him come and take me away if he dare— offer to take me away from my dear Guardian!

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: He shan't, he shan't, ne're fear, I'le defend you.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: You won't sight with him?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Not I beshrew me, I han't so much o'th Cavalier, I thank heaven, to fight and die for my Mistress, that's just like selling ones horse to buy him Provender, so plays fools.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Well go then, and tell him withall that less he makes an end the sooner,
he'l put me to terrible straits and plunges, and make me take some desperate resolution, wou'd I might speak with him, you shu'd hear how I'd rattle him.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: I wou'd you did for me, for I'ave no mind to't, now I know what a dangerous man he is; well, get you in, and let me alone with him.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I go most gladly to avoid his sight, which I so abhor, and hate as I shu'd fear to go even to paradice if he were there.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: I'le marry her, that's certain, for I see she loves me, and there's like to be no love lost if she holds on as she begins,— but let me see, it behoves me now more then ever to look unto my house▪
Where are you there?
HEre Master.
Here Master.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p:
I'd best get a couple of Halberts for them,— come hither I'm to go abroad
d'ye hear, and now be sure you be more careful then ever, to let none enter, especially if any young Gentleman come be sure you keep him out.
I Master.
I Master.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Suppose me the man, now let me see how you'l deal with him.
Get you gone.
Get you gone I say.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Good, and if he go not the sooner thrust him out. Let's see.
Away.
Away I say.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Very good, and if he won't go, beat him soundly, I'le bear you out in't.
Won't you go, I'le make you.
And so will I.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Excellent!
Hold, hold, 'tis well they have no Halberts now, these fools lay on without any mercy;— Now suppose he shu'd flatter you, and say, pray let me in, and offer you money, let's see what you'd do!
sp.stage: They offer to take the Money.
sp.p: What wou'd you take it?
Yes, and then we'd beat him agen for offering it us.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: That's well, They beat him agen. or else I'd beaten you for taking it;— Hold, hold, 'tis enough— I see they are not such very fools as I take them for, or in taking Money all are wise alike.
Well, being so well instructed, go and look well to your charge, and my benediction w'ye.
This 'tis to do things wisely; now will I go and do my other business as wisely as I can.

I'm glad ●h'ave almost done within, there was such eating I thought they wou'd have eat us all; if these be your French Counts and Marquisses, they are the hungryest ones as e're I saw! then they pocketed up more sweet-meats and banqueting stuff then twenty Gossips at a Christning. Oh! here they come at last.

div.head: SCAENA II.
div.stage: Enter the Damoiselles with Mascarillio and Iodelet, and other Gallants, and Ladies for the Ball.

sp.speaker: Mascarillio.
sp.p: VVHat are the Violins come yet?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Let them strike up then, and play me a Corrant, I'le take the hardiess for Prologue to the Ball to dance you a Corranto Ladies.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You'l much honour us.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Faith if his dancing be no better then his singing, the dancing Bears shall dance the Tricotees with him for a wager.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Sa— begin there. Tout beau, tout beau, not so fast, not so fast I say,— firm, firm, en Cadence, en Cadence and be hang'd! Oh Diable! there's no enduring them, Violins de village!

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: They play well enough if he cou'd but dance as well, I knew well enough what a manner of dancer he was.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Come now, lets have our Ball.

div.stage: They dance singly and together, and at the end.

div.head: SCAENA III.
div.stage: Enter Du Buisson and La Fleur, with Cudgels.

sp.speaker: Du Buisson.
sp.p: OH! have we found you! must you be dancing here, and make us dance attendance for you at home? there's musick for you if you'l needs be dancing.

sp.speaker: La Fl.
sp.p: And there.

div.stage: They beat the Laqueys, the rest, all but the Damoiselles run off.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: How now! what insolence is this.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Hold, hold, this was not in the bargain though.

sp.speaker: Du Buis.
sp.p: Had you none, you insolent Rascals, to abuse with your impostures! but these Ladies here whom we both love and honour.

sp.speaker: La Fl.
sp.p: We'l make ye an example for it.

div.stage: Manent the Damoiselles with Mascarillio and Iodelet.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: What's the matter d'ye know?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: The matter's clear, they have been soundly beaten.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Pho! only a wager.

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p: Ne're trouble your selves, all this is nothing.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: D'ye make nothing of a beating then!

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Pho! a hundred such things as these pass amongst Friends.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: For you, your Gallantry priviledges you from fighting; but for him so great a Soldier, and so brave a man, Brave upon brave, a three pyl'd brave.

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p: Why there 'tis now, the more valiant, hardier to provoke to anger still; but when their anger's up once, woe to those who provoked them.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Were they but here agen you shu'd see now how we wou'd handle them.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Behold them here.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: They look methinks as if they cou'd wish them away agen.

div.head: SCAENA IV:
div.stage: Enter Du Buisson and La Fleur agen with Servants.

sp.speaker: Du Buisson.
sp.p: THere, strip them, strip them, that that these Ladies may see when their borrow'd Plumes are of, what pittiful Jack-Dawes they are.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why who are they?

sp.speaker: La Fl.
sp.p: Why Ladies if you'l needs have the naked truth, these are our Laqueys.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: How! Laqueys!

sp.speaker: Laqueys.
sp.p: At your service.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: I knew what manner of Counts and Marquesses they were.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Were ever any so abus'd!

sp.speaker: Du Buis.
sp.p: Right Ladies, and that makes us so severe in punishing them.

sp.speaker: La Fl.
sp.p: Nor is this but a light preparative to the punishment we mean to inflict on them at home.

sp.speaker: Du Buis.
