sp.p: Dispatch, dispatch there.

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p: There goes the County.

div.stage: As they take away their Cloths.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: And there the Marquisat.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am so confounded and asham'd I know not what to say, nor what to do.

sp.speaker: La Fl.
sp.p: Our shame and confusion is no less then yours, that any who had any Relation unto us, shu'd presume to offer ye this injury and affront.

sp.speaker: Du Fl.
sp.p: And we beseech you to believe we had no hand in it, but only in the punishing it.

sp.speaker: La Fl.
sp.p: And if you think them not sufficiently punished, we leave them w'ye to punish them more; and so for this time we take our leaves.

div.stage: Manent the Damoiselles and Laqueys stript to their shirts and Calcons.

sp.speaker: An:
sp.p: Get ye gone ye Rogues, how dare ye tarry here, considering how y'ave abus'd us:

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: We only tarry to know what farther service you please to command us, if you need one now to run a race for you behold your man ready stript:

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p:
And I to do the double supersault
for you, if you love feats of Activity.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: Away ye Rogues, away.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: This! to Counts and Marquesses.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Yet dare ye usurp those Names?

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p: Why not, I'm sure if we were elsewhere, we might pass for such, and no body question it.
Who pays us for our Musick here?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Ask Monsieur le Count.
Will you Sir?

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p: Ask Monsieur le Marquess there.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Why thus goes the world, when men once are fallen into adversity every one falls upon them:

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Hark ye, hark ye Sir, do you know me I pray?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: The waiting woman too!

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: D'ye remember how you'd have deboiched me to day? now cou'd I find in my heart to beat you for't, but that y'ar sufficiently beaten already.

div.head: SCAENA V.

sp.speaker: Bonhomme.
sp.p: VVHere are these Bagages? where are these Damoiselles a la mode here?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My Father, here! then we are sham'd for ever!

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Here's fine doings! fine Revels w'ye, is there not?
Monsieur Du Buisson and La Fleur yonder have told me all; you must have your Counts and Marquesses, no worse men serve your turns,— and are these they I pray?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: All that are left of them.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Get ye gone, and that presently too, or I'le not leave you so much as your skins, but strip you of them as others have of your Clothes.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Come Brother w'ad best be gone and leave this ungrateful place where men of our good parts for singing and dancing are no more rewarded.

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p: And where naked vertue's not lookt upon, but men are more regarded for their Cloths, then for themselves.

div.stage: Manent the Damoiselles and Monsieur Bonhomme, &c:

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Go, get you in too, for I'm too angry w'ye to chide you now, but when my anger's over once, expect to hear from me, and that soundly too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Come Sister lets go and think on some way of repairing our honours.
Will you pay us for our Musick Sir?

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: I marry will I, there's payment for you, and there agen, must you be fidling here amongst the rest? I'le fiddle you.—

I'am vext at heart with these foolish Baggages, and shall be more; when once 'tis known in Town, we shall have the Boys hoot them as they pass the streets, and call one Madam the Countess, t'other Madam the Marchioness: besides, I fear th'as quite broke off the match with these Gentlemen and them;— I must go seek to make all whole agen, or else I shall not know what to do with them.

YOnder's the house, but I know not what's the matter, I'm nothing nigh so forwards to knock as I was wont to be; but fall back fall edge: I am resolv'd, yet softly, softly Sganarelle, for fear of angring him,— and see here he comes already, now han't I breath enough to blow up the bladder of a whiting mop.

sp.speaker: Valerio.
sp.p: IAm inrag'd, that I can think of no expedient to free her from this savage beast?

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: Peace, yonder he is.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Methought I heard him say, he was inrag'd. I'm more and more afraid of him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Now Sir what news with you? you'r never without some or other I know.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Pardon me Sir, I'm afraid I trouble you too often.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not a whit, not a whit, ne're fear it.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: Has strangely chang'd his Tone and Countenance, what e're's the matter.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: But I am but a Messenger, you must consider.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I do consider it.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: The Rogue's abominably afraid, now I perceive, fogh! how he stinks!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And what says Madamoiselle Isabella? for I know you come from her!

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Why she commends her t'ye, and says that she is credibly inform'd you intend a terrible Ryot on my house, and to come to night and take her away by force.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: Slid! she but instructs thee what thou shu'dst do.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Well, and what more?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p:
And says, that if you make not an end the sooner, you'l put her to terrible
straits and plunges, and make her take some desperate resolution.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Poor soul! it grieves me at heart to think what straits and plunges indeed I put her to;—
But do's she say this indeed?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: If you wont believe but go along with me, and you shall hear her say so much her self;— I must do any thing to content him.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: Slid take him at his word.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Well Sir, since you'l needs have it so, I'le go along w'ye, though unwillingly.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: I can't blame you, for I'le warrant ye a sound chiding:— I'le but go a little way, and call you presently.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: We'l go along w'ye if you please.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Pox on him! wou'd I were well rid of him.
I'le instantly be here agen.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: what need you make more labors then one of it? we'l go together;— Come.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: What before you Sir! pray.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Beseech you.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Never Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nay't must be so.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: To obey your commands then since you'l needs have it so, and shew you the way.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: This is the first time I think that ever he Complemented.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: 'Tis strange indeed! but what i'st fear can't do?
that tames wild beasts, and makes him civil too.

sp.speaker: Bonhomme.
sp.p: COme ne're deny it, I know it was your plot, and thank you for it, thank you heartily, they may well stile you their Esculapius, you have done so miraculous a cure on them, to let them see their follies and vanities, see them to their shame, and shame unto amendment.

sp.speaker: DuBuis.
sp.p:
If't be so w'ar most glad of it, for we confess we love them, love them heartily; but were their Beauties and their
Fortunes centuplied, we wou'd not marry them as they were before;— I love a little noble Pride in Women, but hate a disdainful one.

sp.speaker: La Fl.
sp.p: And I a little vanity in the sex, it shews handsomly in them, for vanity in women it is like allay in Coyn, a little no ways abases it, but renders it only more ductil and pliable.

sp.speaker: Du Buis.
sp.p: But in such excess there's no enduring it, and all our whole Estates in a year or two, wou'd be set flying after the mode and fashions, and one half acre of St. Germans Fayr wou'd consume a hundred of ours in the Country, only in toys and trifles.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Never fear, for I tell you th'ar quite chang'd from what they were, and never Circes so transformed others, nor Proteus himself, as you have transformed them.

sp.speaker: La Fl.
sp.p: If it be so, 'tis well; but still we doubt it.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: And if you won't believe me, but go along with me, and believe your selves.

sp.speaker: Du Buis.
sp.p: Well, once more we'l venture; but if once more we find our selves deceiv'd—

sp.speaker: Bonh:
sp.p: Ne're trust me agen; for more assurance; I'le go before, and leave you to come after, mean time pray put your selves a little more i'th mode and fashion.

sp.speaker: La Fl.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: For a Certain reason I have, womens affections follow their eyes, and the way to take the one is to take the other first, they love to see men gallant and fashionable, and the neglect of it, they take as a neglect unto themselves.

sp.speaker: Du Buis.
sp.p: Well, for this once we'l follow your advice.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Pray do, you'l oblige me in't, and so farewell, within this hour I shall expect you.

sp.speaker: La Fl.
sp.p: And we shall not fail to come.

div.head: SCAENA IX:
div.stage: Enter Sganarelle, Valerio and Ergasto, a Song within.

sp.speaker: Sganarelle.
sp.p: THat's she that sings there:
So, now tarry here a little, and I'le go fetch her strait, but expect a sound chiding.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.p: And I deserve it, I know not with what face to look on her, but I hope she'l be so merciful to think t'has rather been want of ability then will, that I've obey'd her commands no sooner, and that occasion has rather been wanting unto me, then I to it.

div.head: SCENA X.
div.stage: Enter to them Sganarelle and Isabella.

sp.speaker: Isabella:
sp.p: NOw what i'st you'l shew me?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: That which you'l wonder to see I'm sure:

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Some fine sight I'le warrant you:

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Look! d'ye see who's yonder!

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Ha! Valerio!

sp.speaker: Sgan:
sp.p: I knew you'd wonder to see him here.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Help me dissimulation, or else I shall betray my joy to see him.
And was't you that brought him hither?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Who else dost think?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Y'ave done very well, and I'm much beholding t'ye, to bring such Gallants as these unto your house; I wonder what you mean by it!

sp.speaker: Sgan:
sp.p:
Nay, be not angry now,— I only brought him to hear confirmed by you what I have told him from you; as
first, that you observed well enough how he follow'd you, and the amorous glances he gave you too.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: All this I bid him tell you.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Go too then, these are Truths I hope,— and you wou'd not believe me now;— then for the Letter.—

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I confess I sent that too.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Go too then, these are truths I hope still,— and did you not bid me tell him you were inform'd he intended a terrible Ryot in my house, and to come to night and take you away by force?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I did so.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Very good still all these are truths I hope.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: And that if you made not an end the sooner you'd put me to terrible straits and plunges, and make me take some desperate resolution.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: All this he told me too:

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Very good then, all these are truths I hope still.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
And are you not asham'd all this being so, that I woman shu'd send unto ye so oft, and you a man shu'd never answer
me; or only by words, not by effects and deeds:— Was this done like a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Well said, I told you she wou'd chide you; but thou dost not chide him enough.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I confess your Reproaches are just, but I beseech you to consider all the difficulties I had, and believe that I'm more unfortunate then criminal.—

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Well then, for your greater satisfaction (if yet you be not satisfied) know there stands a couple of you, of which the one I love, the other hate as much.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Mark that now.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: The one is all my pleasure and delight, t'other all my pain and torment.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Mark that agen.

lg.l: T'one, finally, I'd have for Husband rather then my life,
T'other I'd sooner die— then be his wife.
Does this content you now?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: I child of mine own Education, it does; and in sign of it— there kiss my hand.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: A special favour.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Well, now if you be satisfied, will you get you gone!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes Lady, I go, and since I well perceive who 'tis you love, and who you hate so much, I shall soon rid you of his hateful sight.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Pray do then, and know in any one Action you can't oblige me more; for I confess I'd rather see a Basilisk.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Aye, say not so.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Thou'lt kill him quite, dost not see how sad he is already;— poor man! I pity him, but I cannot cry.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Nor shall you laugh long I hope.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: What are you here still, I thought you had been gone with a nose thus long at least;— now I'm on mine own dunghill I may crow over him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'Tis well Sir, you'r a happy man that may tarry here whilst I must part from hence; yet shall I never repent my love to her, nor envy her's to you.

sp.speaker: Sgan:
sp.p:
Do what you will, so you get
you gone, for you know she can't endure to see your face, wherefore I pray try a little how she'l endure to see your back.

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: How I cou'd beat the Rogue!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Come, come, lets go and never mind him.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: So, so, 'tis very well, Oh what a comfortable sight it is yet a little more,— so now 'tis well.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Fie, fie, you jeer him most unmercifully.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: No 'tis you, this was but a little pleasant Raillery; but thou wert too bitter with him, i'faith thou wert; that of the Basilisk kil'd him quite: I'le marry thee presently for that conceit.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: I am resolv'd on't, and tomorrow morning fresh and fasting I'le dispatch the business.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I'm justly plagu'd for my dissembling,— you wont have time sufficient to prepare and put all things in readiness so soon for the Wedding, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: I'le warrant you a little preparation will suffice.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Nor I to provide my Wedding Clothes.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: There's no need of provision.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: My Cousins will look to be invited too.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: I'le none of these Invitations, 'tis but an unnecessary charge and trouble.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: No way to prevent it!— Oh! I feel my self very ill on the sudden.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: 'Tis but a qualm that presently will over, I'le but go and see the writings drawn and look to find you well at my return.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: But pray let me not be molested then, for I'le to bed, and hope a little rest will make me better.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Do, and sleep soundly; and so good night.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
What shall I do? this makes me desperate, and just like those who fly great fiers, rather consider what it is they fly, then whither 'tis they go; so to avoid his hateful Nuptials, I must do somewhat, and care not what I do.
The worst is dying, and howe're death be Hateful enough, 'tis lovelier yet then he:
HAving consulted all my love and hate, I am resolv'd by favour of the night to leave this loathed house, and take my flight unto Valerio's, I know there is danger in it,
But those who weigh all dangers may befal e're they resolve, shall ne're resolve at all.

sp.speaker: Sganarelle.
sp.p: SO, I've got the writings drawn.—

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Aye me! Who do I hear?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Let me see if I have not lost them.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Envious Fortune! that never yet were't friend to vertuous love, hadst thou no time but now to declare thy self an enemy?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: No, here they are, I was afear'd I'd lost them.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Fixt and surpris'd 'twixt fear and strong desire,
I neither dare go on, nor yet retire, this is such a misfortune, there is no remedy against but poyson and precipices.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: So now I'le go home.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: But this is not a time to spend in vain complaints, Somewhat I must do.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p:
Holla! who goes there? I'm
afear'd 'tis Valerio come to steal Isabella away,— Oh for three blanks of courage more, for what I have will hardly serve my turn.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: It shall be so;— who's there Guardian.?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Isabella!

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: What make you here? you said you were ill, and meant to go to bed, and I thought y'd been in your first sleep o're this.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: And so I had, but for an extraordinary accident that happen'd me.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: What accident?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Not so hasty I beseech you,— Why just as I was ready to go to bed, who shu'd come to visit me but my Cousin Madamoiselle Mary.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: At this time of night?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Yes Sir, and what d'ye think her business was?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Nay— I know not.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Nor cou'd you imagin I'le warrant you— I wou'd I cou'd—

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: VVhat was't? ha!

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: VVhy Sir, having heard it seems that Valerio intended to come and steal me away to night▪—

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Oh? that shews that it was she who gave you the intelligence of 't:— well on.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: VVhat does she, but intreat me of all loves that she might come and take my place to night.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: And so be stoln away instead of you?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Right Sir.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: But why this?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Why Sir you must know she has lov'd Valerio long, and quite despairing of all other ways, she wou'd needs try this way to gain his love▪

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: And so put a trick upon him?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: She's nothing else but tricks I think;— and wou'd you consent to this?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Oh no Sir, but I disswaded her all I could, and told her what a dishonour it wou'd be to her, and to my self, till seeing all my disswasions were in vain, I seemingly at last consented, intending
privately to ask your Counsel and advice in it.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Where is she?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Within Sir.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Why then go presently and turn her out of doors, I'le no such tricks play'd in my house, and why are you out of doors at this time of night?— let me examine that.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Why only to see if I could ' spy you coming, I did so long for your coming home.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Oh! 'tis well,— well▪ go your ways, and do as I bid you:— Where is she! let me come to her, you shall hear how I'le rattle her.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Oh by no means Sir, you'l shame her quite, and me too, for she'l think I have betray'd her t'ye; rather let me by fair perswasions seek first to send her hence, and then if that wont do, use your discretion▪

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Do't any ways so you rid the house of her.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: And as she passes by, pray seem to take no notice of her▪

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Well, well, at your request I will not,— go and dispatch presently:

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: So, thus far all goes well, Aside: now muster up thy whole self Isabella to deceive him, and get away from him, the rest were only light assayes, but this when it is done shall be my Master-piece.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Here's brave doings! and fine order in my Consins house, I have heard of all their Rex to day, and wou'd not for twenty pound but have heard of it; but this surpasses all, to have his Daughters rambling abroad at this time of night alone, and on such Errants too! were she my charge, I'd break the neck of her; but Isabella is far from doing thus, thanks to her good breeding and education▪ But where are my Urchins, I'le talk with them for this; where are you there?
HEre Master.
Here Master.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: VVhy ye Changlings▪ ye Ideots.
'Uds so Master's angry!

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Did not I charge you to look well to my house, and let none enter whilst I was abroad, and d'ye let your Damoiselles Errant in!
Oh, Oh, Oh.
Oh, Oh, Oh.
VVhy d'ye beat us? we saw none indeed:

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Therefore I beat you, you negligent Dog-boults, for you shu'd have seen them, and kept them out too;— VVell, go your ways, and as you like this, look better to your charge hereafter.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p:
I perceieve that those who care not how things are done, may trust others▪
but those who'd have them well done indeed, must trust unto themselves; here after I'le look to my house my self, and then deceive me those who can. Hark! I hear some stiring within, I think she be coming forth.

sp.speaker: Isabella within.
sp.p: VVell Cousin to disabuse you, in fine, your stay is all in vain, there's no Valerio comes here to night, I can assure you, my careful Guardian has ta'n order for that, wherefore I pray be gone.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: I like her well, she tells her plainly of it without dissembling.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: As for my Clothes you may keep them, and send them me to morrow morning, and so good night; you'l excuse me that I do not wait upon you out.

sp.speaker: Sgan:
sp.p: Now, now, she's coming, I'le stand close and observe her.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: NOw Night, put on thy darkest mantle, and hide me in't.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: So— I'm glad my house is rid of her, which way goes she? what directly to Valerio's? Here's a desperate wench now? cares not to put fire and tow together, we shall have a brave flame of it anon.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: This is the house, now Love after so many storms and dangers past, here let me find a happy port at last▪

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I Am resolv'd I'le either die, or free my Isabella from her Captivity.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Live, live Valerio, for behold her here▪

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Ha! Isabella?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: But you lie▪ though, for all your counterfeiting her, and her voice so well.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I fear now my Valerio may less esteem his Conquest of me, having gain'd me so early as has done.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Rather the more, the more a thousand times, for what we gain with difficulty we use to attribute chiefly to our own industry, but coming by you so easily as I do, I must attribute all the thanks to you.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I fear I shall be seen here▪

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Come in then dearest, and hide you in mine Arms.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: But by the port o'th Temple I dare not enter, Honour forbids it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You are a thing so sacred, you make each place a Temple where you are: Mean time your scrupulous honour needs not fear.
By that port only you shall enter here.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: So, get you together with all my heart, pity two houses shu'd be troubled w'ye, and I'm glad mine's rid of you: Now cou'd I but meet mine honest Cousin to confer notes together, how I shu'd laugh at him? and see in good time he's here.

sp.speaker: Sganarelle.
sp.p: OH Cousin! my dear Cousin well; met, I'm heartily glad to see you well.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: And I you; y'ar grown very kind and Complemental of late methinks! I'm glad to see't, 'tis a good sign.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Right Cousin, a very good sign, a sign that all goes well, and I congratulate w'ye.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p:
Why for the high advancement
of Madamoiselles your Daughters there.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: To what I pray?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: To the Dignity of Countess and Marchioness;— and how I pray does the honourable Lords the Count and Marquess their Husbands?

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Y'ar very pleasant.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Have I not reason? being allied unto such noble Personages? and where I pray is your Daughter Madamoiselle Mary, if one might be so bold to ask?

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: VVhy at home I think.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Oh! you do but think so; but I shu'd be asham'd were I as you, and she my charge, not to know for certain where she were.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: But why d'ye ask the question?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: For a certain reason I shall tell you presently, d'ye know that house I pray? and who lives there?

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: VVhy Mounsieur Valerio as I take it.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: You take it right, and thereby hangs a tale:

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: VVhat tale?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p:
VVhy of him and your Daughter,
and both together; for the plain truth is, she's run away from you, and has marryed Valerio.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: It cannot be!

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Nay, pray heaven it be no worse; and now I hope you see the difference Cousin betwixt our two procedures, yours by the way of mildness and gentleness, and mine by that of rigor and severity.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: I see nothing yet, and shall believe nothing of all you say, until I see it with these eyes of mine.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: If that be all your difficulty, you shall soon see it. Holla! who's within there?

sp.speaker: Valerio.
sp.p: VVHo knocks there?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: None but friends;— Look there, d'ye see her now?

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Why this is Isabella.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! he's deceiv'd as well as t'other there,— conceal your self still, and I'le keep your council since he'l needs be deceiv'd, you shall see how finely I'le deceive: Well, are you contented who e're it be, that he shu'd marry her?

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: I am with all my heart; and are you so too?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: with all my heart too, there's my hand on't.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Why then I thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: How! Isabella!

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Did I not tell you so!

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Poor Sganarelle! how art thou coz'ned then?

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: And now I hope you see the difference betwixt our two procedures, yours by way of rigor and severity, and mine by mildness and gentleness?

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: Now were I a Poet what Lampoons cou'd I make against all womankind.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
As for my portion, by good fortune
Sir 'twas left in your hands by my deceased Father to be paid me at day of Marriage.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: 'Tis confest, and I shall be ready to pay it whensoe're you please to demand it.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Then Sir to you, I've nothing else to say, but only to thank you for the care y'ave had of my good breeding and education:

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p: And is this the fruit of it?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Even such as it deserves, and when I have any slaves to breed hereafter, I'le commend them to your care.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And I thank you Sir for all the good offices y'ave done me of carrying Letters and Messages betwixt us; without whose mediation I confess w'ad never been so happy as we are.

sp.speaker: Sgan.
sp.p:
Nor I so unhappy▪— mockt and jeer'd on all sides; Well, I dare not be angry with them, but when I'm at home my Changlings shall dearly pay for it;— mean time my comfort is, you have as little joy of your Daughters as I of her here, and have as much reason to grieve for the
marring of their Marriages, as I for the making of hers here.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Y'ar deceiv'd Sir, their Marriages are forwarder then you imagin: And here behold the Bridegroom's come, ready prepar'd for it.

div.head: SCAENA VIII.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Du Buisson, and La Fleur, gallantly Attired, Mascarillio and Iodelet in their Laqueyes Clothes.

sp.speaker: Sganarelie.
sp.p: NAy, if all be Marryed but I, 'tis time for me to go home, and hang my self; but first, though it fail'd the last year, I'le go and preach the end of the World this year infallibly.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p:
So, now I like you, you appear like Bridegrooms, and your selves, and your Mistress, needs must like you too.
What? my Count and Marquess! I am glad to see your Honours well.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Quelque chose Monsieur pour boire vostre sante.

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p: Somewhat to drink your health Sir▪

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: What Counts and Marquesses beg?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Yes in Court Sir.

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p: And out of Court sometimes too.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Well, there's somewhat for acting your parts so well.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Gramercy Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p: We thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Bonhomme.
sp.p: VVEll, where are your Mistresses?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: In the other world I think by this time.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Why yonder's the strangest change and alteration with them, t'one instead of Romances, reads nothing now but spiritual Books, amongst the rest sh'as got the Spur of Devotion, and reads it all day, and I think mean▪ s to lie with't a nights too.

sp.speaker: Du Buis.
sp.p: He shu'd have but a cold bedfellow then that marries her.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: T'other has got the Sick-mans salve, and instead of making Pomatum, studies nothing now but making Salves and Unguents for the poor.

sp.speaker: La Fl.
sp.p: Hei day!

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: And means to go shortly and practise in an Hospital.

sp.speaker: La Fl.
sp.p: There let her practise for me, I shu'd be sorry my wife shu'd smell of nothing but Salves and Plaisters, and talk of nothing but scald heads, aud scab'd skins.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Here's a strange and miraculous Conversion now!

sp.speaker: Du Buis.
sp.p: A conversion and a half! I'd rather have my wife bodily then spiritually proud and vain.

sp.speaker: La Fl.
sp.p: We shall have them preach shortly, and of all things bless me from a preaching-wife

div.head: SCAENA X.
div.stage: Enter Madamoiselle Mary with a Book, Anne with a Gally pot in her hand, &c.

sp.speaker: Du Buisson.
sp.p: OH! here they come.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: And see there's the Spur of Devotion, and there the Sick-man's Salve, let's stand close and observe them.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Look Sister, i'th first part of the Grand Cyrus here, there's the prittiest story of the Belle Incognita, as e're thou re'dst:

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: How's this! is this her Spur of Devotion!

sp.speaker: An:
sp.p: And here's the best Pomatum as ever skin'd Ladies face.

sp.speaker: La Fl.
sp.p: And this her Sick-mans Salve? I'am glad of this i'faith.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Why thou lying Baggage didst thou not tell me they were converted, and had quite left off their follies and vanities.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: And so they have Sir if one may believe themselves, I'm sure they told me so;— Come, come, and leave off your dissembling, you make me be chid for you here.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: 'Tis true, we but dissemble indeed.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Oh! that's well yet:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: For we are truly converted.

sp.speaker: La Fl.
sp.p: What! more turnings yet?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And mean to leave off this vain and wicked world, and betake us presently to a Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Beshrew me if you do, you shall go alone for me, for I'le not follow you.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Come, come, leave this sooling, and talk no more of Nunneries, but think of Marriage; behold your Husbands here:

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Which?

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Why these here, don't you see?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Who, those? with those profane legs there in surplices!

sp.speaker: Du Buis.
sp.p: They'r turn'd Fanaticks!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And those light shuttle-cock heads that look as if they'd fly?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: No, those whom we were to marry, were grave and sober Gentlemen, and far from the folly and levity of these:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sure these are the Lacqueys agen!

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Come, come, leave your fooling I say, I tell you these are they.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: If they be, we are much beholding to them sure, to inveigh against the fashion and the mode, and cry out against vanity, whilst th'ar a hundred times more vain themselves.

sp.speaker: Du Buis.
sp.p: Oh now I perceive what they'd be at▪— no, no, far be it from us to prohibit you any thing you have a mind unto, or seek to be your Masters, but follow the mode and fashions, read Romances, do what you will, you shall find us always your servants▪

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Nay then to shew our selves right women, now we may, we will not, but
thus we throw them all away, which had you sought to have made us do by any other way then gentleness, we wou'd have died e're ever we wou'd have done.

div.stage: They throw away their Book and Pot.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Mean time don't think you have deceiv'd us with your fine plot there, for I hope by what w'ave done, you see we have our plots as well as you, and cou'd too if we list deceive you too.

sp.speaker: Du Buis.
sp.p: We confess and acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And now we'l be idolatrous of the mode no more, nor think that Lady damn'd who's out o'th fashion.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Nor call a leg without Canons, a leg in Herauldry, or Hat without Feathers, the Quakers block.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nor read Romances so long till we imagin our selves, th' Amaranths and Polixens we read of.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: And pray leave off your precious Language too, and speak intelligibly, that I may understand you.

sp.speaker: Du Buis.
sp.p: Enough, enough.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p:
So, so, I'm glad you are so well
agreed;— And now behold this other couple too, who are in Love agree'd as well as you.

sp.speaker: La Fl.
sp.p: Noble Valerio and fair Isabella, we heartily congratulate w'ye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And we with you.

sp.speaker: Valerio.
sp.p: COme Ergasto, where are you in all this joy?

sp.speaker: Erg.
sp.p: Now you have got another Companion, there is no need of me, I may be gone.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That's unkindly said, Ergasto, a friend's my better self, and no companion can be more dear to me then such an one, know him and love him my dear as one whom you and I have special obligation to.

sp.speaker: Bonh.
sp.p: Come, come, 'tis late, and time each loving couple part, to meet agen with greater joy to morrow, to night's a fast, and Venus vigil, to morrow Heymen's feast, to which I invite each one that's here my Guest.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What my Count and Marquess, are you here?

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: At your service.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No,— we'd rather counsel you to continue Actors still, you did your parts so well.

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p: Well then▪
Gentlemen and Ladies you hear what's said, and we are ready for our parts so you'r content, to be Actors still for your divertisement.

lg.l: ANd now what
think ye o'th Damoiselles a la Mode?
We hope none grutches mony th'ave bestow'd
In seeing them; or if that any here
Thinks that for seing them theypaid too dear;
We wish that for the mode & Damoiselles too,
They ne're may dearer pay then now they do.
